newsitem.title: DUBAI: Pakistan says 111 haj pilgrims dead, 100 missing.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan says 111 haj pilgrims dead, 100 missing.

text.p: Pakistan's ambassador to Saudi Arabia said on Tuesday 111 nationals were confirmed dead and 100 were still missing after a fire which killed more than 340 Moslem haj pilgrims last week.
"We have a confirmed death toll of 111 Pakistanis and another 50 are still at hospitals in Mecca," Shahed Amin told Reuters by telephone from Riyadh. "We believe our up-to-date list is complete".
He said six of the injured Pakistanis were in critical condition in intensive care at Saudi hospitals.
"Some 100 Pakistanis are still missing, but this a normal pattern during haj...people go missing and then turn up after a week or so," Amin added.
The fire swept through a key pilgrimage site near the Moslem holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia last Tuesday, gutting 70,000 tents.
Witnesses said many victims were burned, others suffocated from fumes while some were crushed by a stampede. Saudi Arabia said 343 people died and more than 1,500 were injured.
Officials have said identification of bodies was difficult because many had been burned beyond recognition.
Diplomats said that about 120,000 Pakistanis performed the pilgrimage this year, making them the second largest group after Indonesia, which had a quota for 200,000 pilgrims.
Another 50,000 Pakistanis living in Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states took part in the haj, diplomats said.
Amin said he was not sure yet whether the kingdom would release the bodies of victims to their respective diplomatic missions.
"This issue has to be settled with the Saudi authorities. In the past, the practice had been for Saudi Arabia to bury the victims in Mecca," he said.
Saudi newspapers said on Tuesday four Sudanese pilgrims, three of them women, died in the blaze. Other countries have yet to specify death tolls.
The Indian Foreign Ministry said on Monday 281 Indian pilgrims were missing while 202 Indians remained in hospitals.
Some diplomats said the death toll could end up higher than already announced in view of the critical condition of some victims being treated at Saudi hospitals.
"The official death toll is six days old. It is up to the Saudis to provide an update," a Gulf-based diplomat said. "We cannot speak for them."
